abstract.p: Comment on TNT television movie Wilder Days starring Peter Falk; photos; screenwriter Jeff Stockwell says Falk's character was inspired by his own grandparents (M)

block.p: James Morse, known as ''Pop Up'' to his family, has more than a few fantastic stories up his sleeve, and it doesn't take much coaxing from his 11-year-old grandson, Chris, to get him started. Circus ships foundering off the coast of Maine; elephants flailing in the sea: many of the vivid tales feature Pop Up as a worker on a circus boat, encountering adventure everywhere he turns and hanging on by the skin of his teeth in the face of disaster.

But in ''Wilder Days,'' a movie that has its premiere on TNT tonight at 8, Pop Up -- who got his name from the lovely handmade children's books he has spent much of his adult life trying to publish -- has another, more insidious disaster to deal with. His strait-laced son -- Chris's father, John (Tim Daly) -- doesn't believe a word he says about circus boats and faraway cabins built from wrecked ships. And he bitterly resents a childhood during which his father spent too much time on the road trying to sell his pop-up books. Even worse, John's cynicism is infecting Pop Up's favorite listener, Chris (Josh Hutcherson). So Pop Up decides to create an adventure for the three of them: a road-trip in a sky-blue 1959 Cadillac and a final confrontation on a lonely Maine island where Pop Up's tales suddenly don't seem all that far-fetched.

His strait-laced son -- Chris's father, John (Tim Daly) -- doesn't believe a word he says about circus boats and faraway cabins built from wrecked ships. And he bitterly resents a childhood during which his father spent too much time on the road trying to sell his pop-up books. Even worse, John's cynicism is infecting Pop Up's favorite listener, Chris (Josh Hutcherson). So Pop Up decides to create an adventure for the three of them: a road-trip in a sky-blue 1959 Cadillac and a final confrontation on a lonely Maine island where Pop Up's tales suddenly don't seem all that far-fetched.

Peter Falk, who plays the role of Pop Up, explained why he took the part in a recent telephone interview from Los Angeles. ''Like everybody else I'm a sucker for a great story,'' said Mr. Falk. ''And this guy is a great storyteller. When I read the script, there was nothing familiar about Pop Up; everything was unpredictable. In his words, this guy wants life to be spicy. He wants to be intrigued.''
The curious, complex Pop Up figure wasn't made entirely out of thin air. He was, said Jeff Stockwell, the screenwriter, based on at least two people from his own family.
''It would be crazy to call it autobiographical, but I did have a strange set of grandparents,'' said Mr. Stockwell in a telephone interview from Los Angeles.

Like Pop Up, Mr. Stockwell's grandfather built a cabin out of a wrecked ship in Maine. His grandmother, however, was the storyteller, and like Chris in ''Wilder Days,'' Mr. Stockwell would listen to her first-person tales of circus ships, only to learn later that the ship she was probably talking about existed in the mid-18th century, long before she was born.

Despite the reality-distortion, Mr. Stockwell appreciated the stories. ''She pumped me up with a heightened sense of what was going around,'' he said, ''and that indirectly led me to writing and wanting life to be one or two stages more exciting than it is.''
Craig Anderson, an executive producer of ''Wilder Days,'' said one of the most compelling aspects of the movie was the conflict between Pop Up and John.

''Father and son stories don't come along often,'' Mr. Anderson said in a recent telephone interview from Los Angeles. ''I loved the story of these three generations of men who miss each other in the night and then come together at the end.''

Mr. Stockwell said he, too, had communication problems with his father, ''just like any red-blooded American male.'' But he hopes that the main character the television audience identifies with is Chris.
''I very much want the audience to be in Chris's place -- hearing the stories and getting caught up in them, and then wondering on one level that these stories can't be real,'' he said.
And should Pop Up be held accountable for not being there for his son?
In Mr. Falk's opinion, the answer is no: ''In the course of the story he knew he was wrong, and he was trying to make up for it. And, as he says, everyone deserves a second chance.''
